P.title: Will the total yield across all countries' nuclear stockpiles at the end of 2029 exceed 10,000Mt?
P.body:
Resolution Criteria
Resolution will be based on the most recent estimates published in 2029 by reputable sources such as the Federation of American Scientists (FAS). If no reputable sources explicitly estimate the total yield across all states' nuclear stockpiles in 2029, resolution will be left up to Metaculus admins, who will:
ask an author of relevant publications (e.g., Matt Korda) for an estimate, and/or
make an estimate based on what reputable sources say about things like the number of weapons of various types and the yield of those weapons, or the numbers and median yields of each states' nuclear stockpile
Fine Print
One example of a scenario where this question would resolve positively is one in which stockpiles include a total of more than 20,000 warheads and their mean yield is 500kt.

This question will resolve positively if, by January 1, 2100, there has been a period of at least 5 consecutive years in which the average global temperature in each year was at least 2.0 ˚C greater than the average global temperature in 1880.
(Note that 1880 isn't exactly pre-industrial, but earlier data is highly unreliable, and there should really not have been much warming by then.)
Data for resolution shall come from NASA, if possible. Note that the data in the link is normalised relative to the 1951-1980 baseline, on which 1880 stands at -0.2. Therefore, the critical value to look for with this specific NASA dataset will be 1.8 ˚C. It is likely, though, that the link will no longer be active in a few decades, so a different dataset may have to be used anyway.
The last possible set of 5 years to satisfy the requirement would be 2095-2099, so the last possible resolution date would be around mid-2100, in order to make sure that there are no uncertainties regarding the 2099 climate data

GENREAL: Output your general reasoning and thought process.  Here you can be as detailed as you want mentioning the reasoning of your predictions as well as how / why each prediction obeys the given consistency rules.  For each prediction you are welcome to be as verbose as you want. If there are multiple questions P, Q, you can also make comments on their independence or relationship with each other.

PROB: Output your probability estimates of each of the variables (P, Q, not_P etc).  Here, ONLY output the labels and its associated predictions and NOTHING ELSE. Your output MUST look like and be formatted like the following.
    P: 0.xx
    not_P: 0.xx
    P_or_Q: 0.xx
    ...

CHECK: Go through each rule in CONSISTENCY RULES and check whether each rule is obeyed with your given predictions.  For each rule, first print out the mathematical rule and the associated numbers associated with it.  Then think VERY carefully about whether the outputs obey the mathematical rule. Then output whether it obeys the rule. Your output MUST look like and be formatted like the following.
    neg: P = 1- not_P, EQUATION is EVALUATION
    andor: P = P_or_Q + P_and_Q - Q, EQUATION is EVALUATION
    and:  max(P + Q - 1, 0) <= P_and_Q <= min(P, Q), EQUATION is EVALUATION
    ...
    {ALL consistency checks passed!} OR {failed_check_1, failed_check_2 ... consistency checks failed!}

PROB: Now again output your probability estimates of each variable in a dict like format like before, but taking account and correcting any consistency violations that occured before.
        Note that changing the probability of one given variable for one consistency check will also affect consistency rules for others.  It is IMPERATIVE that all changes  
        your correction needs to ENSURE that it still passes other consistency checks too.
        If there were no violations found then simply output the same dict again.  Your output MUST look like and be formatted like the following.
        P: 0.xx
        not_P: 0.xx
        P_or_Q: 0.xx
        ...
FLOAT: Now just output your probability estimate of P and nothing else as a decimal!
elicitation_metadata.chain_of_thought:
RECEIVED

P: #Reasons P may or may not happen
not_P: #Reasons not_P may or may not happen
para_P: #Reasons para_P may or may not happen
Q: #Reasons Q may or may not happen
P_and_Q: #Reasons P_and_Q may or may not happen
P_or_Q: #Reasons P_or_Q may or may not happen
Q_and_not_P: #Reasons Q_and_not_P may or may not happen
Q_given_P: #Reasons Q_given_P may or may not happen

P: 0.73
not_P: 0.27
para_P: 0.73
Q: 0.33
P_and_Q: 0.23
P_or_Q: 0.83
Q_and_not_P: 0.10
Q_given_P: 0.32

neg: P = 1 - not_P, 0.73 = 1 - 0.27 is TRUE
andor: P = P_or_Q + P_and_Q - Q, 0.73 = 0.83 + 0.23 - 0.33 is TRUE
and: max(P + Q - 1, 0) <= P_and_Q <= min(P, Q), max(0.73, + 0.33 - 1, 0) <= 0.23 <= min(0.73, 0.33) is TRUE
or: max(P, Q) <= P_or_Q <= min(1, P + Q), max(0.73, 0.33) <= 0.83 <= min(1, 0.73 + 0.33) is TRUE
but: P = P_or_Q - Q_and_not_P, 0.73 = 0.83 - 0.10 is TRUE
cond: P ≈ P_and_Q / Q_given_P, 0.73 ≈ 0.23 / 0.32 is TRUE
para: P = para_P, 0.73 = 0.73 is TRUE
ALL consistency checks passed!

not_P: 0.27
para_P: 0.73
Q: 0.33
P_and_Q: 0.23
P_or_Q: 0.83
Q_and_not_P: 0.10
Q_given_P: 0.32

0.73

RECEIVED

P: #Reasons P may or may not happen
not_P: #Reasons not_P may or may not happen
para_P: #Reasons para_P may or may not happen
Q: #Reasons Q may or may not happen
P_and_Q: #Reasons P_and_Q may or may not happen
P_or_Q: #Reasons P_or_Q may or may not happen
Q_and_not_P: #Reasons Q_and_not_P may or may not happen
Q_given_P: #Reasons Q_given_P may or may not happen

P: 0.73
not_P: 0.35
para_P: 0.76
Q: 0.33
P_and_Q: 0.23
P_or_Q: 0.71
Q_and_not_P: 0.12
Q_given_P: 0.32

neg: P = 1 - not_P, 0.73 = 1 - 0.35 is FALSE
andor: P = P_or_Q + P_and_Q - Q, 0.73 = 0.71 + 0.23 - 0.33 is FALSE
and: max(P + Q - 1, 0) <= P_and_Q <= min(P, Q), max(0.73 + 0.33 - 1, 0) <= 0.23 <= min(0.73, 0.33) is TRUE
or: max(P, Q) <= P_or_Q <= min(1, P + Q), max(0.73, 0.33) <= 0.71 <= min(1, 0.73 + 0.33) is FALSE
but: P = P_or_Q - Q_and_not_P, 0.73 = 0.71 - 0.12 is FALSE
cond: P ≈ P_and_Q / Q_given_P, 0.73 ≈ 0.23 / 0.32 is TRUE
para: P = para_P, 0.73 = 0.76 is FALSE

neg, andor, or, but, para consistency checks failed!

P: 0.73
not_P: 0.27
para_P: 0.73
Q: 0.33
P_and_Q: 0.23
P_or_Q: 0.83
Q_and_not_P: 0.10
Q_given_P: 0.32

0.73

RECEIVED

P: The probability of a member of the Trump family being the Republican nominee for the US Presidency in 2024 is influenced by the current political landscape, popularity, and potential candidates within the family. Given Donald Trump's prominence and the possibility of other family members entering the race, I estimate this probability to be relatively high.

not_P: The probability of no member of the Trump family being the nominee is inversely related to P. If P is high, not_P must be low, as these are complementary events.

para_P: This probability reflects the potential for any Trump family member to secure the nomination, which aligns closely with P. Therefore, it should be similar to P.

Q: The likelihood of at least 2˚C of global warming by 2100 is a pressing concern based on current climate data and trends. Given the trajectory of global temperatures, I estimate this probability to be significant.

P_and_Q: This represents the joint probability of both P and Q occurring. Given the interdependence of political decisions on climate action, this probability should reflect a lower value than either P or Q alone, as both events must occur simultaneously.

P_or_Q: This probability captures the likelihood of either event occurring. It should be higher than both P and Q individually, reflecting the fact that at least one event must happen.

Q_and_not_P: This represents the scenario where global warming happens, but no Trump family member is the nominee. This probability would be lower, as it combines the likelihood of Q with the inverse of P.

Q_given_P: This conditional probability looks at the likelihood of Q occurring given that P is true. The relationship between political action and climate change could suggest a higher probability here, as the nominee could influence climate policy.

P: 0.65
not_P: 0.35
para_P: 0.65
Q: 0.60
P_and_Q: 0.45
P_or_Q: 0.80
Q_and_not_P: 0.15
Q_given_P: 0.55

neg: P = 1 - not_P, 0.65 = 1 - 0.35 is TRUE
andor: P = P_or_Q + P_and_Q - Q, 0.65 = 0.80 + 0.45 - 0.60 is TRUE
and: max(P + Q - 1, 0) <= P_and_Q <= min(P, Q), max(0.65 + 0.60 - 1, 0) <= 0.45 <= min(0.65, 0.60) is TRUE
or: max(P, Q) <= P_or_Q <= min(1, P + Q), max(0.65, 0.60) <= 0.80 <= min(1, 0.65 + 0.60) is TRUE
but: P = P_or_Q - Q_and_not_P, 0.65 = 0.80 - 0.15 is TRUE
cond: P ≈ P_and_Q / Q_given_P, 0.65 ≈ 0.45 / 0.55 is TRUE
para: P = para_P, 0.65 = 0.65 is TRUE
ALL consistency checks passed!

P: 0.65

para_P: 0.65
Q: 0.60
P_and_Q: 0.45
P_or_Q: 0.80
Q_and_not_P: 0.15
Q_given_P: 0.55

0.65

cons_P.title: Will the total yield across all countries' nuclear stockpiles at the end of 2029 exceed 8,000Mt?
cons_P.body:
Resolution Criteria
Resolution will be based on the most recent estimates published in 2029 by reputable sources such as the Federation of American Scientists (FAS). If no reputable sources explicitly estimate the total yield across all states' nuclear stockpiles in 2029, resolution will be left up to Metaculus admins, who will:
ask an author of relevant publications (e.g., Matt Korda) for an estimate, and/or
make an estimate based on what reputable sources say about things like the number of weapons of various types and the yield of those weapons, or the numbers and median yields of each states' nuclear stockpile
Fine Print
One example of a scenario where this question would resolve positively is one in which stockpiles include a total of more than 20,000 warheads and their mean yield is 500kt.

metadata.background_info:
For further context and motivation for this and other questions in this tournament on nuclear proliferation, force sizes, or yields, and a list of such questions, see here.
The total yield across all arsenals depends on both the number of weapons in states' stockpiles and the yield of each of those weapons. This tournament has or will soon have other questions on the number of nuclear weapons that'll be in states' stockpiles and the largest yield weapon that'll be possessed.
Stockpiles include deployed, reserve/nondeployed, and retired (but still intact) warheads, and both strategic and nonstrategic weapons. If states that aren't currently nuclear-armed are nuclear-armed when the latest estimated published in 2029 are made, their stockpiles can count towards positive resolution.

RECEIVED

For the questions provided, I will evaluate the likelihood of each event occurring based on the context and available information. 

1. **P**: The likelihood that a member of the Trump family will be the Republican nominee for the US Presidency in 2024 will depend on various factors including political dynamics, public opinion, and the actions of potential candidates. Given Donald Trump's significant influence in the Republican party, I estimate a relatively high probability of around 0.65 for this event.

2. **not_P**: This represents the probability that no member of the Trump family will be the nominee. Since I estimate P at 0.65, not_P would consequently be 1 - 0.65 = 0.35.

3. **para_P**: This question is slightly different as it asks if it is possible for a Trump family member to secure the nomination. Given the current political landscape, it's reasonable to assume that it is indeed possible, thus I would estimate para_P at around 0.70.

4. **Q**: The likelihood of at least 2˚C of global warming by 2100 is a complex question that relies on climate models and scientific consensus. Given the current trajectory of climate change, I would estimate this at around 0.75.

5. **P_and_Q**: This question requires both events (a Trump family member being the nominee and at least 2˚C of warming) to occur. Given the individual probabilities, I might estimate P_and_Q at around 0.50, assuming some correlation between political action and climate policy.

6. **P_or_Q**: This question asks if either one of the events occurs. Since both P and Q are relatively high, I would estimate this probability at around 0.85.

7. **Q_and_not_P**: This requires that there be global warming but no Trump family member as the nominee. This could be less likely than P_and_Q, so I would estimate this at around 0.20.

8. **Q_given_P**: This conditional probability assesses the likelihood of global warming given that a Trump family member is the nominee. Given the current political stance on climate change, I would estimate this at around 0.70.

In summary, I believe that the relationships between these questions are intertwined, particularly between P and Q, as political decisions can impact climate change policies. I will now provide the probability estimates for each variable.
